abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings of the Basic Education
            Subsector Investment Program were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory, risk to development outcome was
            moderate, Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and
            Borrower performance was moderately satisfactory. Lessons
            learned included: (a) Conducive policy environment is
            critical in ensuring the success of a sector program. (b)
            Extension of a project only for narrowly focused
            component(s) may bear the cost of reduced strategic
            relevance. (c) Development Policy Lending (DPL) may be a
            better instrument to support sector policies when
            expenditure items are not completely identified. (d)
            Community-driven school construction and rehabilitation has
            been proved advantageous when there is adequate management
            arrangement and capacity. (e) Decentralized fund utilization
            for service delivery can largely improve absorption
            capacity. (f) Investment focusing on one sub-sector needs to
            be complemented by policy reforms in other sub-sectors. (g)
            Strengthening the technical capacity of the infrastructure
            team within the Ministry of Education will be crucial for
            the continued expansion of school places.
